title: 112_s410
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sunshine in the Courtroom Act of 2011". Federal appellate and district courts are covered under this Act. The term "presiding judge" in this section refers to the judge overseeing the court proceeding, with specific criteria for different court settings. The term "appellate court of the United States" is also defined. The term "appellate court of the United States" includes United States circuit courts of appeals and the Supreme Court. The presiding judge of an appellate court may allow media coverage of court proceedings, with exceptions. The presiding judge of a district court in the United States has the authority to determine if an action would violate the due process rights of any party in a proceeding. This authority is granted notwithstanding any other provision of law, except in specific circumstances. The presiding judge of a district court in the United States may allow the photographing, recording, broadcasting, or televising of court proceedings, with the option to obscure the face and voice of witnesses upon request. The presiding judge may allow the broadcast of court proceedings but must inform non-party witnesses of their right to request their image and voice be obscured during testimony. The judge cannot allow this if it violates due process rights. The presiding judge has discretion to obscure the face and voice of an individual in court proceedings if there is good cause to believe that it would threaten their safety. Media coverage of jurors is not allowed, including photographing, recording, broadcasting, or televising them during trial or jury selection. The presiding judge has discretion to obscure the face and voice of an individual in court proceedings for safety reasons. District court authority for this provision will end 3 years after the enactment of the Act. Interlocutory appeals challenging the judge's decision on media coverage are not allowed. The Judicial Conference of the United States may establish advisory guidelines for court proceedings. The United States may issue advisory guidelines for judges to consider when deciding on media coverage in court proceedings. Within 6 months of the Act's enactment, mandatory guidelines must be established for judges to follow when obscuring the identities of vulnerable witnesses. The guidelines for court proceedings include procedures for identifying vulnerable witnesses and the presiding judge has discretion to set rules for media use in the courtroom. Written acknowledgment of the rules may be required before acquiring any images or sounds from the courtroom. The guidelines for court proceedings include rules for media use in the courtroom, such as no audio pickup of conferences between attorneys and clients. Courts may require accommodations without public expense, and have inherent authority to protect witnesses and maintain decorum.
